Department of Chemistry Indian Institute of Technology Roorkee Roorkee 247667 India Graphical abstract We present here a simple thermal route for synthesizing 5.1wt% cobalt doped CuO nanoparticles (NPs) as the optimized composition of the best heterogeneous CuO catalyst for catalytic reduction of toxic 4-nitrophenol to industrially beneficial 4-aminophenol. The reduction is completed in merely 3min in the presence of 8mM NaBH4 as reducing agent. The optimized catalyst dose was 2mg/L for converting 0.12mM 4-nitrophenol and the corresponding rate constant (k) for reduction reaction was 43.8×10−3 s−1 per mg of catalyst. The catalytic reduction reaction was monitored by UV–vis spectroscopy method and by HPLC analysis. The mechanism is discussed in the light of hydride transfer phenomenon facilitated by large surface area and positive surface charge of the cobalt doped CuO nanoparticles. The cobalt doping resulted in: (a) increasing surface area due to decrease in particle size of the CuO NPs to 10nm, measured by HRTEM; (b) improve stability of the cobalt doped CuO NPs. The cobalt dopant occupied the grain boundaries of CuO to reduce the particle size as derived from positron annihilation lifetime spectroscopy. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analysis of unused catalyst and the spent catalyst revealed occurrence of Co2+ and Co3+ states at the surface. While the X-ray diffraction studies of spent catalyst confirmed the inhibition of reduction of the surface CuO to metallic copper in the presence of NaBH4, attributable to cobalt doping. It was concluded that cobalt doping led to stable and efficient CuO NPs as catalyst for reduction reaction. Keywords CuO nanoparticles Cobalt doping Positron annihilation lifetime spectroscopy Catalytic conversion 4-nitrophenol 4-aminophenol 1 Introduction Nanoparticles are widely being used as heterogeneous catalyst owing to the tunable property of size, shape and structure [1–3]. The salient feature of a heterogeneous catalyst is its ability to bind with target molecules and facilitate electron transport or hydride transport for reduction reactions and should be able to release the reduced product after completion of the reaction to sustain the process. In this regard, nanoparticles have unique advantages with respect to synthesizing tailor-made size and shape of nanoparticles for enhancing catalytic property. Most size and shape dependent catalytic reactions are however confined to metal nanoparticles including the expensive noble metals [4,5]. It may be remarked here about the scope for developing catalyst by neither using noble metals nor compromising the rate of catalytic reaction. In this regard, copper oxide nanoparticles have been well studied as a catalyst for several reduction reactions [6–8]. One of the major challenges of using CuO nanoparticles as catalyst for reduction reaction is associated with reduction of surface copper ions to metallic copper especially in the presence of NaBH4 as a reducing agent [9]. In addition, slow rate of reaction and requirement of high working temperature are the other limitations of using CuO nanoparticles as catalyst for reduction reactions [10,11]. Here we proposed doping of cobalt ions in CuO nanoparticles for better stability of the catalyst and to enhance rate of catalytic reduction reaction. Decrease in the particle sizes of metal oxide nanoparticles by doping with transition metals is a promising feature for improving catalytic activity [12]. This leads to increase in the surface area to volume ratio of the catalyst which would facilitate better binding with the target molecules for catalytic reduction reaction. Besides, doping of transition metals in metal oxides is reported to introduce lattice defects and significantly influence the interfacial charge-transfer processes to facilitate catalytic reactions [13]. In our study, cobalt (Co2+) is chosen as a dopant due to the following reasons: (a) its ionic radii (0.72Å) is similar to that of the host lattice Cu2+ (0.71Å) in CuO; (b) it is reported to be the one of the first non-precious metal catalyst with properties quite similar to that of platinum [14]; (c) because of their large surface area, cobalt nanoparticles exhibit high chemical reactivity [15]; to create more active sites for the reduction reaction and (d) cobalt oxide has been demonstrated to be a catalyst for reducing 4-nitrophenol to 4-aminophenol [16,17]. The purpose of doping was to alter the textural property of the CuO nanoparticles and induce surface defects for manipulating interfacial charge transfer, possibly via the defect sites in CuO nanoparticles doped with cobalt. Moreover, both copper oxide and cobalt oxide species could act synergistically to catalyze the reduction reaction. Reduction of 4-nitrophenol to 4-aminophenol is most widely used model reaction for assessing the catalytic performance of various nanoscale materials [18]. Besides, the other importance of this reaction is conversion of chemically hazardous 4-nitrophenol into 4-aminophenol, where the later is an industrially important precursor compound. For these reasons, the catalytic reduction of 4-nitrophenol to 4-aminophenol was chosen here as the model reaction to study the catalytic property of the different batches of cobalt doped CuO nanoparticles with varying cobalt concentrations. The cobalt doped CuO nanoparticles were synthesized by thermal route and were thoroughly characterized by an array of techniques to establish the size, morphology and composition. Their physical properties like surface defects were studied by positron annihilation lifetime spectroscopy. The stability of the catalyst has been studied and the catalytic reduction of 4-nitrophenol to 4-aminophenol has been monitored by UV–vis spectroscopy and high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) measurements. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of pristine CuO NPs and Co doped CuO NPs The pristine CuO nanoparticles were prepared by treating 150mL of aqueous copper acetate (0.05M) with aqueous 0.3M ammonium carbonate solution and stirred for 1h. In the case of synthesizing cobalt doped CuO nanoparticles, varying concentrations of cobalt acetate, i.e., 2wt%, 5wt%, 10wt%, 15wt% and 20wt% with respect to copper acetate were respectively homogenized followed by addition of 0.3M ammonium carbonate solution. After stirring for 1h, the blue color precipitate was centrifuged and washed with distilled water and ethanol to remove possible remnant ions in the final products, and dried at 60°C. The obtained precipitate was then annealed at 300°C for 2h. The as-synthesized pristine and the doped batches of CuO were characterized by an array of techniques. 2.2 Characterization techniques The X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Bruker AXS D8 Advance diffractometer using the graphite monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.5406Å) in a 2θ range from 20° to 80° at a scanning rate of 2°/min. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were recorded with a FEI Technai-G2 microscope, operated at an acceleration voltage of 200kV. The UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV–visible DRS) studies were performed in the wavelength range of 200–800nm using Shimadzu UV-2400. The photoluminescence spectra were recorded by HORIBA FluorEssence Spectrometer at wavelength of 300nm. The Raman spectra of the pristine and the cobalt doped CuO nanoparticles were recorded on Renishaw inVia Raman spectrometer (serial no. 021R88) using an argon ion laser as the source of excitation (λ=514nm). The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) specific surface area of the nanoparticles were measured by a Quantachrome Nova 2200 analyzer at liquid-nitrogen temperature using five point analysis of nitrogen adsorption–desorption method. The chemical constituents in the pristine and Co-doped CuO nanoparticles were determined from X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) using multi-technique surface analysis system of Omicron Nanotechnology, Germany. The XPS analyses were carried out using monochromatic Al Kα X-ray source of 1486.7eV, with an operating voltage of 15kV and emission current of 15mA. The positron annihilation lifetime spectroscopy (PALS) measurements were carried out using a fast–fast coincidence system consisting of two 1 in. tapered off BaF2 scintillators coupled to XP 2020Q photomultiplier tubes. The prompt time resolution of the system using a 60Co source with 22Na gate was 290ps and measurements were done by using 22Na source embedded in thin Ni-foil. The positron lifetime spectra were de-convoluted using the PATFIT88 code after incorporating necessary source corrections due to thin Ni foil [19]. The magnetic property of the cobalt doped CuO nanoarticles was studied at 300K and at 5K by Vibrating Sample Magnetometer attached with a pulse cryocooler (CRYNOGENICS Ltd. UK). The concentrations of cobalt in the doped CuO NPs were determined by Inductively Coupled Plasma − Optical Emission Spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Agilent 720). The concentrations of cobalt in the respective batches of the acid digested (conc. HNO3) pristine and doped CuO NPs were calculated against the calibration plot obtained by analyzing known concentrations of standard cobalt ion solution. The concentration of cobalt in Co-doped CuO NPs was calculated using the formula given below: C o ( w t % ) = mass of Cobalt in acid digest ( mg ) mass of Cobalt doped CuO NPs digested ( m g ) × 100 The mass of cobalt (Co) in acid digest was estimated by measuring Co concentration by ICP-OES. The HPLC analysis for monitoring catalytic reduction of 4-nitrophenol to 4-aminophenol was performed using Shimadzu LC-2010AHT attached with D2 lamp and UV detector. The mobile phase was isocratic mixture of de-ionized water and methanol at the ratio of 60:40 (v/v). A C18G (250mm×4.6mm) column with a particle size of 5μm was used. The test samples of 20μL were injected and the gradient flow rate was maintained at 0.8mL/min. The oven temperature was set at 40°C. All chemicals and reagents used in this study were of analytical grade and were used as such without any further purification. 2.3 Methodology for catalytic reduction of 4-nitrophenol to 4-aminophenol The catalytic reduction of 4-nitrophenol to 4-aminophenol was carried out using aqueous solution of sodium borohydride at room temperature in presence of pristine (i.e., undoped) and Co-doped CuO NPs as a catalyst. The 0.12mM 4-nitrophenol solution was mixed with 8mM NaBH4 solution in 1:1 ratio to make 500mL solution. Then 2mg/L of catalyst was added to the solution and UV–vis absorption spectra were recorded till the peak due to the presence of nitro group disappeared completely. The reduction of 4-nitrophenol to 4-aminophenol was further confirmed from HPLC analysis. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of Co doped CuO nanoparticles as catalyst The ICP-OES analysis of the batches of CuO nanoparticles doped with initial cobalt concentrations of 5wt%, 10wt%, 15wt% and 20wt% Co-doped CuO NPs were found to be 1.02%±0.08wt%, 1.40%±0.10wt%, 3.40±0.10wt% and 5.10±0.14wt%, respectively. The concentrations of cobalt in the doped CuO nanoparticles are given as mean±standard deviation of triplicate analysis. Henceforth the batches of Co-doped CuO NPs will be referred in terms of exact dopant concentrations. The structural analysis of the different batches of Co-doped CuO nanoparticles were compared with pristine CuO nanoparticles from their XRD measurements, which revealed Bragg reflections at (110), (002), (200), (20 2 ¯ ), (020), (202), (11 3 ¯ ), (002), (31 1 ¯ ) (220) (311) (004) planes (Fig. 1 ). The XRD pattern matched with the JCPDS Card No. 48-1548 and confirmed monoclinic structure. With the increase in the dopant Co concentrations the following observations were made in the respective XRD patterns: (a) the peak intensities decreased; (b) the peaks were broadened; and (c) there was no shift in the peak position. The decrease in the peak intensity is attributable to reduction in the crystallinity of the CuO NPs. This might be due to increase in the doping induced lattice strain phenomenon [20]. The peak broadening is attributable to various reasons, e.g., formation of smaller particle size, defects in the lattice structure due to metal ion doping [21]. The average crystallite sizes gradually decreased from 18nm for pristine CuO to 13nm for 5.10wt% of Co doped CuO nanoparticles (given in Table-1). No peak shift was observed in the Co doped CuO samples, which is attributable to similar ionic radii of Co2+ (0.70Å) and that of the host Cu2+ (0.73Å). Consequently the lattice constants and the unit cell volume were similar for both doped and pristine CuO NPs (given in Table 1 ). However the dislocation density (δ) and the lattice strain (ϵ) were found to be systematically high in the batches Co doped of CuO nanoparticles as compared to that of pristine CuO NPs (given in Table 1). It should be mentioned here that the batches of CuO NPs prepared with initial cobalt concentration higher than 20% did not exhibit good XRD patterns and hence they were not studied further. The observed poor XRD pattern for higher Co dopant concentrations is attributable to large lattice strain leading to poor crystalline nature of CuO nanoparticles. The magnetic characterization of the 5.1wt% Co-doped CuO NPs indicated a ferromagnetic response similar to that of cobalt oxide [22]. The magnetization (M) of the Co-doped CuO as a function of applied magnetic field (H) recorded at 300K and 5K is given as supporting information (Fig. S1). The temperature of the magnetic ordering for both the cobalt oxides (i.e., Néel temperature of CoO=291K and that of Co3O4 =40K) are less than the room temperature. The shape of M-H curve obtained at 300K therefore clearly revealed the presence of magnetic phases corresponding to the oxides of cobalt. The magnetization increased when recorded at 5K and at ±3T (0.19 emu/g at ±3T), which is attributable to restriction in the spin flipping at lower temperature, which led to better alignment of magnetic moments. These studies confirmed weak magnetic property of Co-doped CuO NPs due to cobalt oxides. However the role of oxygen vacancies in the Co-doped CuO nanoparticles on the observed room temperature ferromagnetic property could not be ruled out [23]. The pristine and the Co doped CuO nanoparticles were further characterized by Raman spectroscopy. Both the pristine and the Co-doped CuO nanparticles revealed three Raman active modes, i.e., at 297cm−1 corresponding to the Ag1 mode and the two peaks at 344cm−1 and 629cm−1 corresponding to the two Bg modes, as revealed from Fig. 2 [24]. Notably, the characteristic Raman shifts for cobalt oxide were not observed in any of the doped batches. Therefore formation of cobalt oxide phase in the Co-doped CuO NPs may be ruled out. However, in the batches of Co-doped CuO NPs, the Raman peak intensities decreased with increase in the dopant concentration. Furthermore, a significant peak broadening was also observed for all the three peaks (values are given in Table 1). The decrease in the Raman peak intensity could be attributed to the lowering of the lattice symmetry of CuO due to cobalt doping, and the Raman peak broadening is attributable to increase in the phonon confinement with decrease in particle sizes [25]. The decrease in the particle size of Co doped CuO nanoparticles was evident from high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM). The average particle size of the pristine CuO was 25±5nm (Fig. 3 a), while the particle size of the 5.1wt% Co doped CuO nanoparticles was 7.5±2nm (Fig. 3b). The polycrystalline nature of the pristine and the doped CuO nanoparticles was confirmed from the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern (Fig. 3c and d). The crystalline nature of the pristine CuO nanoparticles was evident from the lattice fringes observed in the high resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) images, where the inter-planar distance for (002) plane was determined to be 0.254nm (Fig. 3a inset). However, such lattice fringes were not well resolved in Co-doped CuO nanoparticles. The decrease in the particle size due to doping could be attributed to stabilization of smaller sized nanoparticles owing to occupation of the dopants (Co2+ ions) at the grain boundaries of CuO. The dopants at the grain boundaries exert drag force on boundary motion which opposes the driving force of grain growth, due to which the crystallite size decreases [26]. The decrease in the particle sizes of the Co doped CuO nanoparticles resulted in increase in the surface area, as evident from the BET surface area measurements given in Table 1. The BET surface area for pristine CuO was 22.97m2/g, while the surface area increased systematically with increase in the doping concentration of cobalt. The maximum BET surface area (55.69m2/g) was recorded for the batch of 5.1wt% Co doped CuO nanoparticles. 3.2 Band gap of Co doped CuO nanoparticles The band-gap of pristine and the Co doped CuO NPs were determined from the Tauc’s plot, given as Supporting Information Fig. S2(a–e). The diffused reflectance spectrum of the batches of pristine and Co doped CuO NPs were converted to absorption spectra by the Kubelka-Munk (K-M) theory and their respective band gaps (Eg) were estimated using the Tauc expression [27]: (A1) (αhν ) 1/n = A(hν −Eg ) where α, hν and A are the absorption coefficient, incident light frequency and proportionality constant, respectively. In this study, the linear region of the Tauc’s plot were better fitted by assuming direct transition (where n =½) for the pristine and the doped CuO nanoparticles. The linear region of the Tauc plot (αhν )2 against hν was extrapolated to (αhν )2 =0 to obtain band gap of the material. Contrary to a commonly observed inverse relation between the particle size and band gap of a metal oxide nanoparticles [28], the band gap of Co-doped CuO were found to decrease from 3.03eV (pristine CuO nanoparticles) to 2.89eV (5.1% Co doped CuO nanoparticles) with decrease in the particle sizes (Table 2 ). This anomaly can be attributed to Jahn Teller effect exhibited by Cu(II) system. The splitting of the eg orbital in CuO increases with decrease in the particle size and consequently the un-filled eg orbital may overlap with the conduction band of CuO nanoparticles [29]. Further insight on such defect levels in batches of Co-doped CuO and consequential fate of the photoexcited electron–hole pairs was obtained from the room temperature photoluminescence (PL) spectra. The Fig. 4 reveals intense PL emission peak at 413nm and 436nm for the pristine CuO nanoparticles corresponding to near band edge emission peaks, which may be assigned to electronic transition in defect levels e.g. VCu (copper vacancies), Cui (copper interstitial) and Vo (oxygen vacancy) in pristine CuO nanoparticles [30,31]. The energy levels for the copper vacancies and copper interstitials would lie just above the valence band maxima, while the oxygen vacancies would lie below the conduction band edge minima. In the case of Co-doped CuO nanoparticles, the intensities of the PL peaks were drastically reduced owing to trapping of photoexcited electrons and/or holes in some trap state which might have formed due to cobalt doping and the excited state is likely to relax via non-radiative relaxation process [32]. 3.3 Positron annihilation lifetime spectroscopy of pristine and Co doped CuO The positron annihilation lifetime spectroscopy (PALS) was employed to study the nature of defects in the as synthesized pristine and the representative 5.1wt% cobalt doped CuO NPs. The corresponding PALS spectra are given in Fig. 5 . The PALS spectra were de-convulated using three positron lifetime components i.e., τ1 , τ2 and τ3 and their relative intensities I1 , I2 and I3 are given in Table 3 . Since positrons are antiparticles of electrons and they are annihilated with local electrons so the positron lifetimes can be used to probe various types of defects e.g., e.g., copper vacancy (VCu), oxygen vacancy (Vo), Cu interstitial (ICu), voids, cluster defects, triple junction defects. However, oxygen vacancies are not probed by positrons as these vacancies exist as neutral charge state [33]. The τ1 is the shortest positron lifetime component, which corresponded to smaller sized defects primarily at the grain boundaries of CuO nanoparticles. These defects are typically due to copper monovacancies (VCu) or smaller sized voids. The relative abundance (I1) of such smaller sized defects are more in 5.1wt% Co doped CuO nanoparticles than in pristine CuO nanoparticles. The τ2 lifetime component corresponds to a longer positron lifetime and it is attributable to larger sized defects, e.g. vacancy clusters or larger voids. These large defects are mainly located at the surface or sub-surface of nanoparticles [34]. Contrary to the smaller sized defects, the relative abundance of larger sized defects (I2 ) was more in the pristine CuO nanoparticles than in Co-doped CuO nanoparticles. It may be remarked that larger sized defects were annealed by dopants [35]. The τ3 lifetime component is the longest among the three lifetime components and it is related to very large voids that might occur during the synthesis of the nanoparticles. Such defects are negligible in the pristine as well as 3.4% Co-doped CuO NPs as revealed from only 1% relative abundances (I3 ). The average defect size in the samples is a measure of mean positron lifetime (τm), defined as [36]: (A2) τ m = ( τ 1 I 1 + τ 2 I 2 + τ 3 I 3 ) ( I 1 I 2 I 3 ) Notably, the average defects were high for Co-doped CuO than pristine CuO nanoparticles (Table 3). The increase in the overall defect in doped batch was mainly due to higher concentrations of smaller sized defects especially the copper monovacancies at the grain boundaries, i.e., higher I1 with respect to I2 . 3.4 Catalytic reduction of 4-nitrophenol to 4-aminophenol by Co doped CuO NPs The reduction of 4-nitrophenol (NP) to 4-aminophenol (AP) by 5.1wt% Co doped CuO NPs as catalyst and NaBH4 as reducing agent was monitored by UV–vis spectroscopy and confirmed by HPLC analysis. An intense yellow colored solution was formed when 8mM NaBH4 was added to 4-nitrophenol solution, due to formation of 4-nitrophenolate anions in basic medium, which was confirmed from the UV–vis spectrum corresponding to λmax at 403nm, and is consistent with literature [37]. Without any catalyst, the rate of reduction of 4-nitrophenol by NaBH4 was slow. This is reflected from the negligible decrease in the peak intensity of λmax at 403nm over a period of 60min (given as Supporting information, Fig. S3). However, the reduction reaction was rapid in the presence of pristine CuO and more rapid in the presence of Co-doped CuO NPs. Particularly, the batch of 4-nitrophenol treated with 8mM NaBH4 and 2mg/L of 5.1wt% Co-doped CuO NPs as catalyst under normal light illumination led to completely colorless in 180s. It was noted that the absorbance at λmax =403nm decreased with the progress of the reaction, while a new peak emerged at λmax =305nm (Fig. 6 a). The peak recorded at 305nm matched with that of the standard 4-aminophenol, which confirmed the reduction of 4-nitrophenol to 4-aminophenol by Co-doped CuO NPs as a catalyst. The systematic kinetic study of catalytic reduction of 4-nitrophenol + NaBH4 to 4-aminophenol by different batches of pristine and Co doped CuO NPs was followed by Langmuir-Hinshelwood equation given as: ln(Ct/Co )=−kt where, Co and Ct are the initial concentration of 4-nitrophenol and that at any arbitrary time ‘t’, respectively. The data of ln(Ct/Co ) versus time (t) were linearly fitted and confirmed pseudo-second order kinetics (Fig. 6b). Notably, the rate constant (k) obtained from the slope of the plots improved systematically with increase in the dopant cobalt concentration in CuO NPs. The maximum rate constant was obtained for the batch of 5.1% Co-doped CuO nanoparticles (k =43.8×10−3 s−1), which was five folds higher than the rate constant obtained for the batch treated with pristine CuO NPs. Moreover, the rate constant obtained in our study is by far much higher than several non-noble metal/metal oxide as catalyst [10,17,38–51]. A brief review on various non-noble metals/metal oxides as catalyst for reduction of 4-nitrophenol to 4-aminophenol is presented in Table 4 . Compared to all the listed catalyst in Table 4, the batch of 5.1wt% Co doped CuO NPs exhibited significantly higher rate constant for the reduction reaction. Furthermore, the rate constant normalized with the mass of catalyst used in the reaction (referred to as rate activity parameter, k′) was also found to be highest for the batch of 5.1wt% Co doped CuO NPs. The catalytic reduction of 4-nitrophenol to 4-aminophenol by 5.1wt% Co doped CuO NPs as catalyst was further confirmed from HPLC analysis (Fig. 7 a–e). The retention time of 4-nitrophenol and 4-aminophenol were standardized as 5.50min and 3.88min, respectively by spiking their standard solutions (Fig. 7a,e). The HPLC chromatogram of the control batch comprising of 4-nitrophenol treated with NaBH4 revealed a peak only at retention time=5.50min, corresponding to 4-nitrophenolate (Fig. 7b). It re-confirmed that the reduction of 4-nitrophenol to 4-aminophenol could not be achieved by only NaBH4 as a reducing agent. On the other hand, the HPLC chromatogram of the batch of 4-nitrophenol treated with NaBH4 and Co doped CuO NPs revealed two features, e.g., (a) the peak retention time=5.50min diminished with time and finally disappeared; (b) a new peak at retention time=3.88min emerged corresponding to 4-aminophenol (Fig. 7d). The HPLC results therefore corroborated with UV–vis absorption spectroscopy results and confirmed the reduction of 4-nitrophenol to 4-aminophenol by Co-doped CuO NPs as a catalyst. 3.5 Catalyst reusability and characterization of spent catalyst The batch of 5.1wt% Co doped CuO NPs was used for reducing 4-nitrophenol to 4-aminophenol for 8 cycles and the rate constants (k) for each cycle is given in Table S1, as Supporting Information. It could be observed that the rate constant in the 8th cycle was decreased by ∼40% as compared to that in the 1st cycle. The spent 5.1wt% Co doped CuO NPs catalyst after 8 cycles was characterized by ICP-OES, XRD and XPS analysis. The ICP-OES analysis revealed negligible loss in the cobalt concentration in the catalyst. Furthermore, the cobalt concentration in the reaction medium after completion of the reduction reaction was less than 40μg/L. Similarly, the copper concentration in the reaction medium was measured as 135μg/L. These results implied negligible leaching of cobalt and copper from the batch of 5.1wt% Co doped CuO catalyst in the reaction medium. The XRD of spent catalyst, i.e, 5.1wt% Co doped CuO NPs and spent pristine CuO NPs as control catalyst, are given in Fig. 8 . Apart from other CuO phases the spent pristine CuO nanoparticles after 8 cycles of reduction revealed a metallic Cu phase corresponding to (111) plane. The formation of metallic copper phase in CuO treated with NaBH4 was expected, as explained in literature [9]. However, such metallic copper phase was not identified in the case of 5.1wt% Co doped CuO NPs after 8 cycles of reduction. It may therefore be surmised that doping with cobalt led to stability of CuO as a catalyst in the presence of NaBH4. This is most likely due to surface passivation of CuO NPs with cobalt doping, where cobalt is likely to occupy at the grain boundaries of CuO NPs as deduced from positron annihilation lifetime studies. Furthermore, the stability of the cobalt doped CuO NPs as catalyst was confirmed from XPS analysis. The survey scan and detailed scans for Cu, Co and O for the batch of 5.1wt% Co doped CuO NPs catalysts before reduction and after 8 cycles of reduction are given in Fig. 9 . The high resolution XPS spectrum of 5.1wt% Co doped CuO nanoparticles revealed binding energy peaks at 933.1eV and 952.7eV corresponding to the core level Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 of CuO, respectively and are consistent with those reported for CuO [52]. The energy difference between 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 was due to the spin orbit coupling. A series of satellite peaks of Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 were observed at binding energies in the region of 940.9 and 961.6eV which corresponded to un-filled Cu 3d shell of CuO [53]. The high resolution XPS spectrum of O 1s revealed two broad humps which were fitted using three Gaussian components corresponding to three peaks at 529.1, 531.1 and 533.0eV. These peaks were assigned to the O2– ions in the monoclinic structure of CuO, oxygen deficient regions within the CuO and to non-stoichiometric surface oxygen at CuO nanoparticles, respectively [54]. The signature of cobalt in the catalyst was evident from the high resolution XPS spectrum corresponding to the core levels of Co 2p3/2 (779.4eV and 782.5eV) and Co 2p1/2 (794.6 and 797.4eV). The de-convolution of Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 together with spin orbit splitting of 15.2eV is in good agreement with the literature report of Co present in 2+ and 3+ oxidation states [55]. Furthermore, the absence of any distinct satellite peak in the region of 779eV and 794eV also confirmed Co2+ and Co3+ mixed oxidation states, which may be attributed to Co3O4 phase. Most importantly, no shift in the binding energy nor change in the intensity of the peaks of Cu 2p3/2, Cu 2p1/2, O 1s, Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 were observed for 5.1wt% Co doped CuO NPs catalyst before and after 8 cycles of treatment in nitrophenol+NaBH4 solution. This clearly indicated the stability of the as synthesized Co doped CuO NPs catalyst. 3.6 Mechanism of catalytic reduction of 4-nitrophenol to 4-aminophenol Hydride transfer from BH4 − to 4-nitrophenol via metal ions in CuO catalyst is a possible mechanism for catalytic reduction of 4-nitrophenol to 4-aminophenol [56]. As shown in Table 2, all the batches of pristine and the Co-doped CuO NPs in aqueous medium exhibited positive zeta potential values and hence they are favourable for adsorption of both BH4 − and nitrophenolate anions on their surfaces. This would assist a proposed hydride transfer from the BH4 − to the nitrophenolate to facilitate the reduction of 4-nitrophenol to 4-aminophenol. The product (4-aminophenol) is neutrally charged and hence it is released from the surface of the CuO NPs so that next cycle of precursors (BH4 − and nitrophenolate anions) are adsorbed on the surface of the Co doped CuO NPs for sustaining the reduction reaction. The order of surface area normalized catalytic reduction rate constants is: 5.1wt% Co-doped CuO (k″ =78.68×10−5 g m2 s−1) >3.4wt% Co-doped CuO NPs (k″ =51.05×10−5 g m2 s−1) >1.4wt% Co-doped CuO NPs (k″ =10.67g m2 s−1) >1wt% Co-doped CuO NPs (k″ =11.06×10−5 g m2 s−1) >pristine CuO NPs (k″ =9.14×10−5 gm2 s−1). Notably, the rate of catalytic reduction of 4-nitrophenol to 4-aminophenol increased with the increase in the cobalt doping concentration. Further, increase in the cobalt dopant concentration resulted in higher positive zeta potential of the cobalt doped CuO NPs (Table 2), which favoured adsorption of BH4 − and nitrophenolate anions on the catalyst surface for enhanced hydride transfer. From XPS and PALS measurements it was derived that the cobalt dopant species were mostly at the surface and at the grain boundaries of CuO NPs, which favoured charge transfer process for reduction of 4-nitrophenol to 4-aminophenol in merely 3min. This work may be extended to more realistic application by immobilising the Co doped CuO NPs on suitable substrate for greater ease of post reaction separation of the catalyst. 4 Conclusion A simple thermal method has been developed for synthesizing novel cobalt doped CuO NPs of sizes around 10nm. The cobalt doping in CuO resulted in the following features: (a) decrease in the particle size of CuO, which is attributable to inhibition of growth of particles by dopants that acted as a capping agent; (b) occupancy of Cobalt ions at the grain boundaries; (c) anomalous decrease in the band gap of CuO NPs; and (d) increase in surface area. The batch of 5.1wt% cobalt doped CuO nanoparticles was optimized as the best catalyst composition for reducing toxic 4-nitrophenol to industrially useful 4-aminophenol via a proposed hydride transfer mechanism. The catalytic reduction reaction was completed within 3min using a catalyst dose of only 2mg/L, monitored by UV–vis and confirmed by HPLC measurements. The catalytic reduction has been explained by hydride transfer mechanism favoured by cobalt dopants at the surface and at the grain boundaries of CuO NPs. The stability of the catalyst in the reaction medium has been confirmed up to eight cycles of operation via characterizing the spent catalyst by XRD, XPS and ICP-OES measurements. coredata.dc:description: We present here a simple thermal route for synthesizing 5.1wt% cobalt doped CuO nanoparticles (NPs) as the optimized composition of the best heterogeneous CuO catalyst for catalytic reduction of toxic 4-nitrophenol to industrially beneficial 4-aminophenol. The reduction is completed in merely 3min in the presence of 8mM NaBH4 as reducing agent. The optimized catalyst dose was 2mg/L for converting 0.12mM 4-nitrophenol and the corresponding rate constant (k) for reduction reaction was 43.8×10−3 s−1 per mg of catalyst. The catalytic reduction reaction was monitored by UV–vis spectroscopy method and by HPLC analysis. The mechanism is discussed in the light of hydride transfer phenomenon facilitated by large surface area and positive surface charge of the cobalt doped CuO nanoparticles. The cobalt doping resulted in: (a) increasing surface area due to decrease in particle size of the CuO NPs to 10nm, measured by HRTEM; (b) improve stability of the cobalt doped CuO NPs. The cobalt dopant occupied the grain boundaries of CuO to reduce the particle size as derived from positron annihilation lifetime spectroscopy. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analysis of unused catalyst and the spent catalyst revealed occurrence of Co2+ and Co3+ states at the surface. While the X-ray diffraction studies of spent catalyst confirmed the inhibition of reduction of the surface CuO to metallic copper in the presence of NaBH4, attributable to cobalt doping. It was concluded that cobalt doping led to stable and efficient CuO NPs as catalyst for reduction reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Cobalt doped CuO nanoparticles as a highly efficient heterogeneous catalyst for reduction of 4-nitrophenol to 4-aminophenol
